awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChem: Reversible Ionic Surfactants for Surface-Clean, Supported Nanoparticle Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Saunders, Steven R.
Proposal Number: 1651597 
Institution: Washington State University 
Title: CAREER: SusChem: Reversible Ionic Surfactants for Surface-Clean, Supported Nanoparticle Catalysts


The goal of this proposal is to develop methods of synthesizing size-controlled nanoparticles which can be deposited onto a catalyst support without the use of a passivating organic surfactant. Advancements in this field may lead to supported catalysts with very high activities, which will enable cost-effective and energy-efficient production of fuels and pharmaceuticals.   These materials will also enable fundamental investigations into the role of particle size in catalysis. The main research objective of this proposal is to leverage Reversible Ionic Surfactants (RevIS) to prepare highly active supported nanoparticle catalysts that do not require annealing and are more resistant to sintering than traditionally prepared supported catalysts.  The educational and outreach objectives aim to increase the motivation of underrepresented, rural high school students to pursue careers in STEM fields and to enable undergraduate and graduate students to understand and leverage nanotechnology to solve real world problems. 

Reversible Ionic Surfactants (RevIS) are switchable molecules which display drastically different properties when an external physical stimulus is applied. In the proposed work, the RevIS can be switched on to act as an efficient surfactant and then switched off to act as a weak surfactant or non-surfactant. The central hypothesis that motivates the proposed research is based on the assumption that supported nanoparticles prepared via RevIS are more catalytically active without needing to be annealed and less prone to sintering at high temperatures than traditionally prepared catalysts. Monodisperse metallic nanoparticles can be templated by a switchable reverse micelle and subsequently deposited surfactant-free by leveraging the switchable nature of the RevIS. The proposed approach is scalable due to the mild conditions and simplicity of the processing required.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the use of Switchable Surfactants (SwIS), also referred to as Reversible Ionic Liquids (RevILs), to prepare novel catalytic materials. SwIS/RevILs are a novel class of molecules that can be switched between two distinct states using external chemical stimuli. SwIS/RevILs were used to prepare materials at the nanoscale to be used as the next generation of catalytic materials to aid in converting other species into essential chemicals for the energy and sustainability industries. Improved performance of catalytic materials results in lower prices and less waste when producing and purchasing energy, food, and pharmaceuticals.

SwIS/RevILs were used to template and help synthesize gold, palladium, or platinum nanoparticles in one of their distinct states. They could deposit the nanoparticles onto high-surface area support materials when switched to the other state.   Via a fundamental investigation, the mechanism of action was understood, and the process improved.    The fundamental mechanism relies on the SwIS/RevILs forming disordered polar clusters, or microenvironments, to template nanoparticles. When those clusters are destabilized via the switching-action, surface-clean nanoparticles are released and deposited onto the high surface-area support materials via van der Waals interactions.   The particle size was controllable by adjusting the size of the clusters and could be easily maintained through the deposition to yield uniform, size-controlled catalysts.

The catalytic materials developed in this project showed higher catalytic activities than morphologically-equivalent materials prepared by traditional techniques. This SwIS/RevIL preparation technique yielded catalytic materials that required less processing than their traditional counterparts and were more thermally stable under harsh conditions.   When taken together, this project developed a technique that resulted in catalytic materials that were more active and more robust while requiring less processing. It demonstrated that scientists and engineers must carefully consider their synthesis and preparation techniques when choosing and preparing catalysts. 

Since this SwIS/RevIL required less processing, it opened the door to characterizing catalytic processes in previously impossible ways. For example, traditional techniques required that all gold, platinum, and palladium be subjected to high-temperature activation processes before their catalytic use. This was not required for the SwIS/RevIL-prepared materials, and the effect of no or low-temperature activation processes could be investigated. We determined that for SwIS/RevIL-prepared materials, any amount of thermal activation fundamentally worsened their performance. If similar trends exist for traditional materials, most catalyst preparation techniques yield worse-performing catalysts because the techniques necessitate high-temperature processing. 

This project also investigated the breadth of materials this SwIS/RevIL technique applies to. Nanoparticles of gold, platinum, and palladium could be produced on various supports, including non-porous silica, porous silica or ceria, and conductive carbon. It was determined that this technique could likely be easily applied to many industrial catalysts, resulting in increased performance. This investigation resulted in the development of new materials that can catalyze chemistries at much higher activities and selectivities than many traditional counterparts.  

A second aspect of this project was to engage with high school teachers from rural school districts to increase the participation of students from rural school districts in STEM majors at university. Rural students participate in STEM majors and careers at a lower rate than the average student nationwide.  Engagement with high school teachers would ensure that many more students could be impacted over the length of the project and after the project.   Teachers participated in a condensed Research Experience for Teachers, participating in research activities and developing engaging activities for their students.   While the COVID pandemic impacted these activities, several high school teachers could participate and incorporate activities into their classrooms.

Additionally, this research was incorporated into Washington State University's Chemical Engineering curriculum's core curriculum to provide students real-world examples of their fundamental engineering concepts.   The research was incorporated into three courses:  CHE 321 – Kinetics and Reactor Design, where students were able to learn about the fundamentals of catalysis, CHE 485 – Interfacial Phenomena, where students could design materials at the nanoscale, and CHE 432/433 – Unit Operations Laboratory where students gained hands-on experience with using and characterizing catalysts. 

In conclusion, this project had three main goals:

  1. Developing the Switchable Ionic Surfactant/Reversible Ionic Liquid synthesis and deposition technique
  2. Leverage this technique to produce catalytic materials that perform better than traditionally-prepared materials and perform novel, previously impossible investigations to understand fundamental processes at the nanoscale.
  3. Improve the participation and success of students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math disciplines.

Success in this project will yield improved sustainability and economics of various chemical process industries while training the next generation of engineers. 

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2023
Modified by: Steven R Saunders

This project investigated the use of Switchable Surfactants (SwIS), also referred to as Reversible Ionic Liquids (RevILs), to prepare novel catalytic materials. SwIS/RevILs are a novel class of molecules that can be switched between two distinct states using external chemical stimuli. Improve the participation and success of students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math disciplines.


Success in this project will yield improved sustainability and economics of various chemical process industries while training the next generation of engineers.
